what: ACRO: Tools for the Automatic Checking of Research Outputs
title: A Tool for Automating the Statistical Disclosure Control of Research Outputs
text: repository maintains ACRO R package, interface Python ACRO package. ACRO (Automatic Checking Research Outputs) open source tool automating statistical disclosure control (SDC) research outputs. ACRO assists researchers output checkers distinguishing research output safe publish, output requires analysis, output published substantial risk disclosing private data. providing light-weight ‘skin’ sits well-known analysis tools, variety languages researchers might use. adds functionality : identify potentially disclosive outputs range commonly used disclosure tests; suppress outputs required; report reasons suppression; produce simple summary documents TRE staff can use streamline workflow.

previous_headings: ACRO: Tools for the Automatic Checking of Research Outputs > Installation
title: A Tool for Automating the Statistical Disclosure Control of Research Outputs
text: ACRO currently depends numpy version 1.x.x pre-compiled wheels available within pip Python 3.13. Therefore, scenario, numpy must built source. requires installation C++ compiler pip installing acro. Windows, Microsoft Visual Studio C++ build tools likely need installed first. unable install C++ tools, able install multiple versions Python, can use following method explicitly create Python virtual environment desired python.exe. First identify location python.exe needed, may C:\Program Files\ local C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\. R, use reticulate create virtual environment install ACRO; see example . Change path provided version Python path (note forward slashes required path). Finally, R ACRO library can used normal:
code: >>> library("reticulate") >>> reticulate::virtualenv_create(envname = "r-acro-0.4.7", version = "C:/Users/username/AppData/Local/Programs/Python/Python310/python.exe", force = TRUE, packages = NULL) >>> reticulate::py_install("acro", envname = "r-acro-0.4.7") >>> library("acro") >>> acro_init(suppress = TRUE)
